course.name: Artificial Intelligence
course.description: Basic concepts and methods of artificial intelligence including both symbolic/conceptual and numerical/probabilistic techniques.

textbooks.name: Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, 4th Edition

reviews.body:
This was my first course in the program. I did ML in the Summer. Both courses I got an A. My background was an undergrad in Stats and working in the field of Data Analyticsfor 3 years.

Overall, with my background, this was a great first course to get back into school mode. The assignments are auto-graded, so you get immediate feedback, and the exams are very difficult, but week-long so they allow for some leeway in the schedule. A background in Stats paired really well with a lot of the material, such that I could focus on improving my programming/implementation skills. This probably contributes to my reported workload being lower than the average.

Assignments: I found the first assignment extremely challenging, but then something *clicked* and the others went more smoothly. It is the only assignment I didn't get a perfect score on. Coming from a more theoretical background, it was really neat to implement the different algorithms from scratch, and even led to a few clarity moments on stuff like E-M algorithms, Naive Bayes Classifiers, HMMs which I thought of as black boxes before. A2 was my favorite though, building AIs to perform games is just... fun!

I think I should mention, you cannot leverage anything prebuild except approved libraries - the goal is to build these algorithms from scratch and really understand how to implement them. That said, the course focuses less on using the algorithms to solve problems, and more on implementing them, so its usefulness might vary depending on what you're looking for.

I strongly suggest reading the book, pretty much a requisite to do well imo. The supplemental material was pretty interesting as well, and a lot of the times helped, but I would prioritize the book for sure. As well the community of students and instructors on Ed and Discord was amazing.

On workload: Until week 5, I was averaging 19 hours per week on the course, but this number is skewed higher by working 30 hours on the 2nd week of A1. After that, I didn't keep track, but I would be surprised if I worked more than 15 hours on any given week outside the midterm week.

Good and fun class, but when people say its hard, they are not lying. The class is 6 projects, a midterm, and a final, with optional homework assignments along the way. I ended up getting an A in the class but I spent a lot of time on it. I took the class in the summer - I DO NOT RECCOMEND THIS. The accelerated schedule meant that the TAs had to cram things together so much that we had two projects due on the same weekend! 

A lot of people are scared of this class because they think it will require a lot of math. You will probably need to have taken both a Calc 2 and Linear Algebra class to understand some of the concepts here, but that doesnt mean you'll actually need to be DOING any calculus or linear algebra. Most of the actual calculations will be done by python code that you write, but you just need to understand the concepts so that you know what code to write. 

Each project will take approx 20-30 hours of work, and the lectures are not sufficient to teach you the concepts you need to complete the project. You are expected to do additional research as you work through each project to learn the material. The projects themselves are fun, and if you're new to things like ML, Data Science, Neural Networks, etc., then these projects will do a great job de-mystifying them for you. 

The midterm and the final are both fully open notes, open book, no time limit. But they are HARD. They give you one week to complete the midterm and final and you can expect that they will take you at least 3 days each. In many cases, there is material on the exams that is not really covered in the lecture material, and you'll need to do some new research to find the answers. In some cases, they will link you to the material you're expected to use, but in other cases they won't. (This is DESPITE the warning that you're not allowed to use outside materials to help you on the exams!)

For example: the lectures for Module 5 teach you the basics of Bayesian probability, and show that you'll need to do some basic multiplication. Then, for module 5 on the midterm, you're expected to calculate the probability density of the normal distribution (aka the gaussian integral). That wasnt covered at all in the material! 

There are also optional homework assignments along the way. These are small 1-page assignments with a few sample questions on them for you to answer. They were only worth 1% of the grade so I skipped them completely, but the teaching staff mentioned that they were considering increasing their weight for future classes.

The TAs were generally responsive to questions and problems as you had them, and they were gracious enough to give the students the opportunity to argue with the TAs about the correct answers on the exams, in case the question was misleading or could be interpreted differently. Many classes would simply tell you "no, you got it wrong and thats final", so I appreciate this from them. 

Overall, it was a really fun class that I learned a lot, but I definitely had to work for it and I'm really glad its over.

Other reviews have covered the mechanics of the course so I’ll skip that, except to say that this semester, despite being summer, nothing was cut out. All 6 assignments, midterm, final, challenge questions.  I spent around 12 hours a week on average and got an A.  Some weeks were 30 hours and some were 0. 

Overall, this was a fun class and a good intro to AI. The projects are fantastic, especially the ML project where you implement decision trees and RFs from scratch. You need to be pretty good at Python and at algorithms to succeed in this course, but if you’re good at those this is a fun class with a lot of learnings.

Overall there was quality content covered in this course. There is more content than you could reasonably make it through with 15 hours a week in a regular term, Summer term compressed the whole schedule so you either need more time per week or you will miss some depth of the content.

The lectures are very surface level and the staff expects you to read the textbook. While the textbook is interesting in spots it's VERY verbose and describes topics with mathematics frequently. I didn't find it realistic to read the prescribed sections in the time provided.

The assignments were great learning tools and provided good hands-on experience for most topics. With time and effort, these are relatively easy to get 100 on, and you'll pick up knowledge that will help you on the midterm and final.

The midterm and final were relatively approachable - both were week-long open notes (not open Internet). These were a relatively good and fair test of course knowledge.

I've rated this course a 3 for the following reasons:
1. The staff really struggled to meet deadlines. Each assignment had an issue with the autograder, and most of the time these issues went uncorrected for several days. Solutions and midterm/final issues often had discrepancies and the TAs for some sections appeared to put in a minimal effort.
2. The course content is locked behind a fixed timeline. I strongly prefer to work ahead in courses, but assignments are released in either a 2-week window or a 1-week window. This meant some weeks were 10 hours on average, and others were 30. There was one portion of the course where 2 assignments and a midterm opened or closed within 2 weeks, which meant all spare time was dedicated to the course.
3. A massive focus on using only content from the course. There are stringent guidelines about cheating - referencing any material outside the suggested course material without citation is considered a violation. There are topics in the course that we were tested on which had only one sentence of explanation in the textbook. This made learning about some niche subtopics unnecessarily difficult and roundabout.

Overall, the course is worth doing if the topics interest you. Be prepared to self-study and dedicate a fair amount of time if you want to learn the material reasonably well.

Overall the course provided a good introduction to AI concepts, and the assignments did a good job at reinforcing these concepts. The lecture material is very surface level so you'll need to read the textbook in order to do well in the course. 

If you're taking this course in the summer be very aware that around the midterm period you get two assignments that are due in two weeks, along with a midterm that is due in a week. You typically get 2 weeks for 1 assignment so this jump in workload can be very surprising, and imo unfair. 

IMO assignment difficulty from hardest to easiest is A5>A3>A1>A4>A2>A6. Start assignments early to succeed.

Just completed the course during the summer term and got an A grade.

Course grading structure: 6 assignments (average of the highest 5 will be used) + Midterm/Final Exams (exams are take-home; you have 1 week to complete them) + Weekly quizzes (only 1% and unlimited tries).

If you have a strong python background and don’t prefer group projects, this class may be for you. I’m not saying this is an easy class; it requires a lot of hands-on programming (and they are not easy or short scripts), but it is totally manageable. I didn’t watch the course videos, so I cannot comment on them. However, the TAs seemed a little unorganized.

Overall, if you trust your programming and problem solving skills, grade A is doable with some effort and B grade is almost guaranteed.

Relatively straightforward course. For every other week, probably need to spend a day on the assignment, the lecture is pretty short take you about 1 hour to complete each week. An additional 2 - 3 hours of reading is probably nessesary for the project and with the knowledge completing the assignment is about another 3-4 hours.

The AI introduction class was very interesting and covered a lot of material in a short time. However, I found the video lecture very frustrating because it made a lot of assumptions and jumped to conclusions without thoroughly explaining the material. The exception was the video by Davis (not sure about the name, he covers probability and bayes network), which followed a more pedagogical approach.

I don't want to repeat other comments, but I do want to note that the assignments are tough. They are all challenging but doable if you start early and work on them consistently each day. Work with generative AI to understand the concepts. Don't give up—you can definitely finish with an A.

Background: minor in CS in undergrad, working as a dev for a decade. Second OMS class, first AI-related class ever.

The class material and assignments in AI were really good, but time-intensive. The class covered everything from classical search to game AI to ML algorithms. At its core, it's an AI survey class where you implement algorithms. The first half is doable with just good programming skills, but second half ramps up brutally with the math almost like flipping a switch, mainly (Bayesian) probability and some linear algebra. My math background is a work in progress and my last real math class was in the 2010s. I didn't prep much for the math beforehand and just picked up what I needed to on the fly. But the better you are at Bayesian probability and in general with reading and understanding arcane math notation, the easier the class will go. I found the second half of assignments more difficult than the first half, but those with a stronger math background got through them more quickly and easily than I did. Conversely, because of my background, I'm probably a stronger programmer than many of the students who are fresh out of school or Jr devs and found the first couple assignments easier, though still quite time consuming. Start working on assignments the day they are released. I spent between 12 and 19 hours in-editor working on the code for each assignment.

The class is organizationally a mess, run 99% by TAs, and the midterm and final exam both had a week of corrections afterwards with much drama abound (TAs write the tests from scratch for each semester). On one hand, it's very clear the TAs try to make the tests fun, engaging, and relevant educational opportunities, so a round of applause to them for the effort. When the questions worked, they worked and felt like fun puzzles rather than test questions. But on the other hand, the questions and answers are riddled with errors. The staff claims they go through a QA process, but I suspect the process can be improved. Both my midterm and final grades went up by double digit percentage points by the time corrections were over because of errors the TAs made in either the questions or their answer keys. Additionally, the tests threw in questions about concepts that were not covered or expected knowledge, like Q-learning or the details of convolutional networks. Great idea in theory, but stressful and pedagogically questionable to throw on an exam without advance notice. The plagiarism/honor policy is weird and has a chilling effect on collaboration. But despite this, there was a super active Discord with a good sense of community and commiseration.

I skimped on the readings, but at least skimmed through all of them. The textbook is a good resource, but gets dense with math notation, especially in the ML sections. While using outside resources like watching YouTube videos, reading Wikipedia, or chatting with ChatGPT to understand a concept would have been a forboden violation of the class' plagiarism/honor policy and so I did not do any of those things, I certainly thought about doing those things but definitely did not act on those thoughts in order to better understand the material or get a better background for the material.

So overall a mixed bag with with challenging and interesting material where I learned a lot in spite of needless drama, frustration, and difficulty because of the class's implementation. Worthwhile? Ultimately yes, but be prepared to spend a lot of time and be a little frustrated. I spent 175 hours total on the class, peaking at 21 hours one week, but with most weeks being closer to 14 hours of effort on average. I got an A, but definitely didn't get everything I could have out of the material just because of time constraints with work/life.

This class was pretty intense and time consuming, but I felt that I learned a lot at the end if it.  I would say this course starts out harder and gets a little easier, I found that projects 1 and 2 were the hardest and took the longest for me.  The lectures were all pretty good with pretty good explanations.  The textbook readings started out pretty good but later on in the course they were pretty dry and had a ton of math that was hard to follow, so I didn't get much out of the textbook in the second half of the course.

I had high hopes for this class after taking AI4R. I was excited to dive deeper into the AI world and gain more experience. But here's how the class went:

TLDR. It sucked. Too little depth in lectures, and super disorganized. 

Week 1 we received a notice that the teacher would be unavailable due to a cruise in antarctica(super jealous!). then we received notice that the Head Ta would also be on a cruise... in antartica. Both cruises were unrelated. This lead to a chaotic start to class where the regular TAs were unable to determine if a homework assignment was due or not due by the first Friday. This chaos did not settle when the teacher and TA arrived back, all we received was a short email stating they were back and the homework in question now was an extra credit. Yay! that was probably the best part of the course, a 1% extra credit for a homework that had nothing to do with the lectures or book. 
This class has the most asinine honor code. You may not learn ANYTHING outside of class or its cheating. Want to watch an outside lecture to learn the subject better? Cheating. Want to read more about it outside the book? Cheating. The entire class was walking on eggshells the entire semester. There were constant reminders every week on how many students they catch cheating every semester. over 50% of the communications in this class were about cheating. Seriously, we get it. most of us will not cheat. We came here to learn. 
The lectures were a high level overview with nearly no depth. there was some comedic parts which was nice. But there was no substance. Occassionally they would add in a video from another professor without any introduction. Horrible quality and I had to turn my headset on mono mode because the audio was coming through only one ear.
The book is written for statisticians and gives one example(if you are lucky) of each lesson you are learning. 
This class was dubbed "ARTIFICIALLY DIFFICULT" by the students and I agree. I wish I could get my time back from this class as I learned nothing from it.

Chose this over ML based on my experience with RL being difficult and shaking things up was the right choice I think. RL was a harder class then this.
In a nutshell the first half of the class is AI and the second half is ML.
It's a tough class, and assignment 1 is downright hazing it's so absurdly difficult. The rest of the class is reasonable, but hard. Exams are easy because you get all the time you need to think, but I recommend taking vacation days to make use of the time you get so you're not distracted or worn out. I took days off for both exams and I'm glad I did.
Each assignment has a 2 week window to complete it in and the exams are week long to week and a half long take homes exams.

Utilize the resources provided in the assignments themselves - the instructor attaches pdfs that should be the first thing you look at for guidance before looking at other course content. The lectures have a tiny shred of homework relevance not the usual zero relevance, so watch them. The course is disorganized and what you're expected to do on assignments will never be written in one single place. Many times assignment rules only exist in an obscure Ed Post so have fun figuring out what you're supposed to do. Often times you have to check 5 ed posts, the git page, the jupyter page, and then you'll have all of the rules to follow from the assignment that exist fragmented in all those random place. This professor is the antithesis of organization.

Assignment 1: 85 hours in 2 weeks, 85/10
Description: A* but way more complicated than the other 10 times you've learned it. REMEMBER: No neighbor caching!!!

Assignment 2: 20 hours in 2 weeks 100/100
Description: Gaussian Mixtures: Submit infinitely until you randomly get 100.

Assignment 3: 22 hours in 2 weeks 100/100
Description: Bayes Net: Just remember your last stats class.

Midterm: 16.5 hours in 1 week 81/100
Description: This is how exams should be made period. Having only 2 hours or less is a meaningless measurement of learning. Here you have a whole week.

Assignment 4: 16 hours in 2 weeks 100/100
Description: Decision Trees - Getting feedback from gradescope can take long on this one. Get ready to wait.

Assignment 5: 9.5 hours in 2 weeks  100/100
Gaussian Mixtures - Know how Numpy works. 

Assignment 6: Skipped
Description: Not worth my time since I did all the other assignments. Really glad I did assignment 1 because I was extra busy during this assignment.

Final: 17.5 hours in 1.5 weeks 84/100
Description: Just like the midterm. This one is comprehensive. The exams in this course are the best part. Having time makes it so easy for slow thinkers like me.

This was my second class in the course, with RAIT being the first. I have no formal background in CS, ML, or AI but I do professionally and work with very experienced professionals in the fields.

This is a very good class, but some things hold it back from being an excellent class. 

The Good
+ This course is very informative in what it teaches
+ Most topics I have now applied in my work, or have listened to talks of other people applying them at my work and I was able to follow along in a way I could not before
+ The textbook is one of my favorites I have read with great information I look up for work
+ Projects are pretty well defined and give you a good grasp on the important things
+ Some of the TAs are very very good (Shoutout to Raymond)

The Bad:
+ Tests.... There is no way around this one. For this semester there were so many questions on the final where the answer key was just incorrect or easily could be multiple answers they initially did not accept, but ended up accepting after a lot of posts on Ed. If an answer was accepted they never gave a rationale/explanation for the new or old answers which ended up making what I had previously thought I learned correctly more fuzzy than before, diminishing the overall learning experience. Also, exam corrections were coming out during the testing period all the way until the day before it was due... Causing people to resubmit new tests with the new information given (which caused another issue I will get to later)
+ TA/Prof Communication... This is directly related to the above bullet as most communication came about with the confusion of the exams. Initially for the midterm they claimed that partial credit may be awarded for submitted answers via pdf. Once the test concluded it was revealed in a comment buried deep in the discussion board that this in fact was not going to happen (unless an extreme Canvas issue). This point was never universally clarified by TAs or the professor. In fact, many TAs kept claiming that this pdf grading was still up to individual TAs when it was not causing more unnecessary confusion. The prof is non-existent in the class apart telling us he was back from vacation and a single clarification of a midterm answer. Since this is online I was expecting this, but I think when things devolve to the level that it felt like it did then the professor should step in and clarify it for all students.

Neutral/Hearsay
+ Anti-cheat... I'll start by saying, cheating is bad and people diminish their own learning when they do so... However, the "fix" to cheating should not be worse than the cheating itself. And for some unfortunate people this seemed to end up being the case, especially on the final. I was fortunately not part of this, but people were claiming that due to the automatic anti-cheat software they were given a grade of "I". This supposedly led to people having their graduation and summer enrollment messed with. This was claimed to be derived from people submitting their finals too quickly when it was likely just them fixing a single answer due to them changing the test while we took it. Also it was claimed that this "sophisticated" anti-cheat software was being tested on the class. I put this in the neutral/hearsay category because I am just going on what other's posted in Ed. So take this with a grain of salt since I do not have direct experience and it was a limited subset of students who seemed to be adversely effected when they did not supposedly cheat. 

Even with these testing frustrations I secured an A and was able to spend less time than average on the class.

Some things that helped me that may be helpful for others:
+ I spent very little time on the lecture videos. I found them less helpful than the textbook and ended up only watching specific videos when I was still confused about something. This overall saved me a lot of time
+ Most projects, in my experience, are much easier to get the first 95% and then the time it takes to get that final 5% is disproportionate. So if you feel confident you don't need that last 5% then you can likely save yourself many hours. 
+ I found a class like RAIT to be a good way to ease myself into the subject. There is quite a bit of overlap in the class concepts, but RAIT is a bit more simple. So if you are feeling less confident and you want/need to take RAIT I would highly recommend taking RAIT first.
+ I was already very familiar with python and numpy. If you are not familiar with python I would recommend just doing some quick tutorials to learn the syntax (I find it to be the most simple of commonly used languages). Numpy is not allowed until around half-way through, but getting acquainted before that point would prove useful as it becomes the basis/required for the rest of the projects as they start having more strict timing requirements.

Overall, this class is a really good and informative class, but it could really use some more care during the tests. Ultimately the tests made a class that I would have happily given a 5 into a 4. Though, I think with better question vetting and better communication that this class could very easily be a 5 in my book just based off of the content learned and the project's hands-on support of that learning.

I did CS for undergrad and took an AI course then, so I figured this would be an easy first class. Alas, that was not at all true. For the first assignment, the equivalent of an entire project I did in undergrad was just the warmup, and the assignment ended up taking me about 25 hours, and I still didn't get full points, I just gave up and took a B. 

Despite the difficulty, the class was very rewarding. The assignments were difficult and took a long time, but they really helped me understand the concepts at a deeper level. Sometimes the textbook went so deep into the math that my eyes glazed over, but it's in general good, and CS is  mostly just math in a trenchcoat so I know I signed up for this.

The reason I'm not giving this class five stars is because it's horribly disorganized. The exams were full of errors and ambiguous questions that were not corrected in a reasonable time (and sometimes not at all). There was miscommunication over when a couple of things were due. Also, some people (luckily I was not one of them) were mistakenly flagged as cheating in the final, and received an I as their final grade with no explanation, and it took several days for a TA to respond and correct it. 

I ended up with a low A - I did well on the assignments, which helped me with my lower exam grades (both low Bs). I think this class is worth taking, even if you've taking AI in undergrad, because it probably didn't go nearly as in depth as this one. Be prepared to spend a long time on assignments (15-20 on average for 6 assignments for me), and probably don't take this with another class unless you have a ton of free time.

I went into this course fully aware that it is difficult, but it still took my by surprise. 

For the first assignment, I ended up spending more than 40 hours and still did not get a 100%, but with the next 5, i put in half of that time and managed to get the 100. This was my saving grace since the exams were very ambiguous. I was truly disheartened after the first assignment and would have dropped off if this werent my last chance to finish this particular course (I has some personal constraints forcing me to complete Masters soon).
I had also coupled this with Intro to cognitive science course and there were a few weeks when I was seriously contemplating if I had bitten off more than I could chew, but as my luck would have it, I was laid off work at the start of the semester, and I put in all my effort into getting these two courses done. This Spring saw me with my nose buried in the books, my kids counting down the days the courses end to see their mother emerge from her cocoon again. 
I have some feedback to both the students who are contemplating this course, and the course coordinators.

Students: Try not to take this course with any other. Also, give it your all for every single assignment and every single exam. You can expect a lot of uncertainty in this course, for example, in the wording of the exam questions, or the percentage split for the results, etc.
Attack assignments as soon as they release, so that you can make use of the office hours, find that TA or two who are responsive on Ed and try to get their time on the OH to get your doubts clarified.
The Discord channel is a huge blessing for this course, do make use of it. You will find a lot of tips that will help you do your best on the assignments. 
The TAs also release walkthrough videos for every assignment, a couple of these were extremely helpful for me to complete the assignments. Ensure you go through these.
Be mentally prepared to be tuned in to Ed, Discord, going through lectures, assignments coding, (maybe) challenge questions etc all at once. So time management is super critical. If you get overwhelmed, talk to people on Discord, make use of the student communities out there. Some of these folks can really help you rally through the course.

Staff :
I have seen recurrent feedback from students over the semester about the ambiguity of the question framing. For some questions, more than 80% of students have chosen the same answer, which means it is more misleading than ambiguous. It would be great if the staff would address these in the coming semesters. 
I feel the plagiarism fear is so rampant for this course that students really hesitate discussing among themselves, even at a whiteboarding level. Also to say that use of any and all unofficial sources is not allowed and amounts to plagiarism, might not be the best way forward considering the textbook is extremely cyptic and the lectures do not (and cannot) go through everything in detail. 

Overall, this course left a definite impact on my life. It was challenging, some of the assignments left me feeling fulfilled and when I saw the final grade , I felt fulfilled. But, it has more than a few kinks which need to be ironed out.

Really good course in terms of setting foundational knowledge and introduction to AI. However, it requires a lot more hard work to gather this knowledge vs other courses. The lectures barely cover what is needed to succeed in the course and you really need to read the book multiple times to get in-depth understanding of the concepts. There are 6 assignments which are super interesting though only the top 5 are considered for the final grade. The assignments become progressively harder. The exams are open book but really test your knowledge and can take upto 20-30 hours to finish. Overall start early to keep up with the pace; there’s a slight curve which hovers around the official cut-offs (A>=90, B>=80 etc) but dont rely too much on it.

I enjoyed the course but there is a lot of content crammed in. The assignments were challenging but enjoyable. I found the discord group really helpful for assignments and discussions post-exams. Definitely try to do well in the assignments, I only submitted the first 5 and didn’t attempt the last one as they only count the best 5 grades. Midterm and final exam were not difficult but make sure to read the questions carefully and ask for clarifications. I only lost marks where I found the question was not clear. This was raised as feedback during the midterm and the TAs took this on board and communication was better during the final exam.

Intro Assignment: 1%
Plagiarism Quiz: 4%
Assignments: 60%
Midterm Exam: 15%
Final Exam: 20%
Exercises: 1%


There are a total of 6 assignments, but the lowest grade will be dropped. The assignments were challenging, so it's best to start them at least 7 days in advance (you usually have 2 weeks to complete them). 

There are no group projects in this course.

There were two exams in this course, one midterm and one final. Both exams were open-book and take-home, but not easy, and all multiple-choice questions. Remember to double-check your answers and grades, as there were many instances of exams being misgraded by TAs this semester.

Tracking ED posts is a good way to help you succeed in this course.

There’s some great content here but the way this course is run is a train wreck. I don’t understand how it’s so bad after ten years. 

The content is good. It’s a survey of the whole AI field, with a mix of good old fashioned AI and ML. It’s helpful to get a perspective on how ML fits into ways of thinking about AI in general. 

Most of the difficulty is artificial. Things are made deliberately obscure or confusing and they think that proves something. It feels like a hazing instead of a learning experience. 

The assignments are decent. There’s six and your best five count for most of your grade. They’re chunky but give a decent idea of different algos and approaches. Rack up as many points as you can here. 

The exams were so bad. Neither was too onerous or long, but quality control was way off. Pretty much every question on both exams needed clarifications. The biggest problem by far was question wording. They loved writing a page of irrelevant background, and then make the actual instructions ambiguous. Then mark 90% of the class wrong for choosing the more normal interpretation. Both exams followed by days of challenges on the forum. I’ve never seen anything like it in seven years at uni. 

The prof is absent and has farmed everything out to his grad students. Who don’t seem to care because it’s not their main job, and responsibility is diffused among a big group. 

There was also an unhelpful us vs them vibe from the start. The TAs seem to care more about preventing cheating than anyone learning anything, and they’ll assume you’re cheating rather than just confused by their misinformation. You’ll also be told that you can’t read around the subject or look at any outside materials. Another thing I have never seen before. What is a university doing forbidding you from learning?

I learned some good stuff and got an A but I won’t miss this clown show.

The course content is interesting and the projects are pretty fun. The lectures and textbook are helpful, though they could use more walkthroughs and examples.

The class itself is a mess. Just expect typos/mistakes/ambiguity in everything, especially the midterm and final. I had to redo the same questions 4 times because the TAs kept changing the questions during the test. Check the Ed Forum daily and join the student Discord group! The students are the ones who find fixes and answer questions. The TAs are out in the wild. We have 25 TAs but you rarely see them answering questions. Not sure what they're doing since assignments and tests are auto-graded... There are office hours, which is nice, but do be mentally prepared to wait for 40+ minutes to get in and constant no-shows. Ask questions early because you might get responses from TA three weeks before the final that they're "too busy writing the final" to answer your questions. The professor had office hours here and there but completely disappeared after the midterm. 

I highly recommend getting a head start on the lectures/reading if you can. It'll help you jump right in with assignment 1 which is the longest one. Luckily, Raymond's in charge of that one and he's super awesome! His videos, especially final review, are very helpful too.

Lastly, I wanted to share that I did not have a CS or math background. It's definitely a tough class but it's doable and rewarding if you're able to invest the time. The students in this class are friendly and willing to help so just ask questions if you're stuck. Good luck!
The topics discussed in the course are very interesting. The projects do take time but you learn a lot.

This is the course that convinced me that reviewers on this site tend to give higher quality ratings to classes that are more difficult regardless of whether they actually deserve high scores. This academic version of Stockholm Syndrome is the only way a subpar course like this can get a 4+ rating here on OMSCentral. It's not quite as bad as the trainwreck that is GA, but at a 4+ it's so galactically overrated that it boggles the mind. 

* The workload is just too high. I don't think it's a problem to an absurd degree, but 3-credit classes should generally strive to stay under 15 hours per week of work, or certainly at least under 20. The ~25hr/wk workload is currently the 6th highest of courses reviewed from OMSCS. I'm a pretty average student and this estimate feels correct to me, but I skipped most of the extra credit and other challenge problems. Most assignments feel 20-40% longer than they should be. 

* The workload wouldn't be as bad if it was spent actually learning things, but WAY too much time is spent dealing with weird edge cases that aren't essential to understanding the algorithms. Edge cases happen in the real world, but there they can be easily debugged. The Ed discussion forums for this class were an unfortuantely essential resource since it's where other students would reverse-engineer the jank of the assignment. Ed discussion forums should be for additional help, not "the other half of the assignment instructions we just didn't tell you". 

* A very common and frustrating occurrence was when I'd pass all local tests, but fail on the Gradescope submission. I always felt completely helpless when this happened, as Gradescope was a black box that said little more than "hmm that's not the answer I was expecting". I would run through my code step by step confirming everything worked locally, but it still wouldn't pass. With non-descriptive errors, I could never be sure if Gradescope was failing due to a genuine bug on my end, some janky edge case, or an issue with Gradescope itself (which happened several times throughout the semester). Something like 25%-40% of all Ed posts were "everything works locally, but GS fails", so the problem was obviously widespread. We really need better error messages so we can at least attempt to resolve issues ourselves. 

* The TAs did not seem on the ball in Ed discussions, often replying late and with incoherent answers that were indicative of not understanding either the question being asked, the content of the assignment, or both. It was typically up to other students to get an actual answer to problems being faced, which was obviously not very reliable since it depended solely on the comraderie of others facing the same issue. I saw many questions that just went completely unanswered for 48+ hours. You want to start assignments early to account for this, but not too early so others hopefully have a chance to deal with the weird edge cases before you spend hours dealing with them yourself. 

* Ambgiuous assignment directions. It started OK with first few assignments, but context gradually declined. In some of the later assignments you're forced to implement functions with little more than a one sentence docstring. It was pretty common for me to have to work backwards from the unit test provided to figure out what was even being asked for. 

* Lots of math equations that are just theorem dumping with no examples or broader context to explain what's happening. There's very little enlightenment in much of the textbook and supplemental reading. Far too often I'd be implementing an algorithm and I'd come across a math symbol that I had absolutely no clue what it was referring to. Also, some like |E| would typically refer to the absolute value of E, but then sometimes refer to the determinant of E. Untangling this stuff can lead to more frustrating hours of debugging. 

* The lectures are very handwavy and don't even begin to prepare you for the assignments or the exams. 

* Exams have almost nothing in common with the lectures or assignments, and are very all-or-nothing. I recommend getting a digital copy of the book so you can ctrl+f    

I got an A in this course, but despite the high grade I actually learned surprisingly little.

First paper in my OMSCS, got an A. 
Really difficult but rewarding course. Definitely requires the time commitment stated. Even though the curve is super lenient (getting above class median gets you an A) the class level was also super high, so I believe the cut-off ended up being 89-90% anyway.
The course will require you to be able to give 15+ hours a week throughout the length of the course - as such, taking this course with any vacations planned would be inadvisable. I was unable to give 15+ hours for some of the latter weeks, band made catching up nearly impossible in time for the exam.

My background is in Civil Engineering and my coding experience before the class was limited to an introductory MOOC from HarvardX on Computer Science + the intro classes from Gatech on Java and Data Structures and Algorithms. In the end I managed to get an A.

I would definitely recommend this class.
This was my first class in the OMSCS and I easily spend 50+ hours on the first few assignments (35-40 towards the end), so if your background is similar to mine, make sure you are able to put in the necessary work.

If you use all the resources that are given to you (especially the video lessons to understand the assignments), you have a good chance at doing well in this class.
The book is a great resource, and I recommend reading the chapters before doing the assignments, because the assignments align very well with the book.

I tried to keep up with reading the papers given in between the video lessons, because they were were very interestring. However, towards the middle of the class, I have to admit I gave up a bit on them because of the heavy workload...and to be honest, they were not really necessary to get the A.

For interaction with students, Ed and the Discord group have been my two main sources of help. The TAs I had contact with were most of the time not familiar with the specifics of a given assignments, only once I was actually given good guidance. Often, they did not even show up.

The exam was tough and long, but forced me to repeat some of the more theoretical concepts very well. I didn't do great in them, because in my case. especially the topics on probability pulled my grade down.
The grading process is a bit chaotic, but in the end, I think people were treated fairly.

The professor made a nasty comment in the first class, saying that he expects the in-person students to kick the online student's a** which I found pretty arrogant and demotivating. It turned out in the end, that the live lessons were not necessary to get an A.
That does not mean that I don't recommend thinking through the exercises and discussions they have during class. It was just really hard to follow along, because the recording process was very messy (unreadable white board writing, bad sound quality, things out of focus, people not speaking into the microphone, etc.).

Took 7 courses. This is the most difficult one among all. Without adequate math knowledge and background, it is unlikely you will survive in this course. I finished Calculus III, linear algebra, probabilities, etc prior to taking this course, still once a while got stuck. It is an extremely difficult course, and I ended up in quitting job to spend 90 hours a week (15 hours a day!!!) working on it. It was toooo difficult. Please do not take it until you are ready for it. If you do not have any math background, or if you are not good at math, this is NOT a choice for you.

This class was quite difficult and to make matters worse, the teaching staff did not do a great job in making clear of the expectations in this class which resulted in a lot of last minute panic and confusion. For some reason, this class was combined with the undergrad courses so we had the opportunity as OMSCS students to attend the live lectures but it felt very disconnected and unproductive at times. This class had a lot of potential to be a cool course but it ended up being extremely stressful and burdensome as I was also working a full-time job (as most OMSCS students). The class discord was a life-saver! But overall, would not recommend this course if you are unable to commit to putting 15+ hours each week, especially if you do not have a strong technical background. Those starting with OMSCS, please do not pick this as your first 2/3 courses as that was a mistake I made and I experienced severe burn out.

TLDR: Expect to put more time than what you are expecting to put each week. This class has difficult and tedious projects and start as early as you can to ask questions.

The good: 
- Lectures and textbook provide a fascinating look at some foundational AI work: planning, HMMs, game playing, Bayes’ nets, etc.

- There's enough here to learn about the general approach to solving complex, multi-faceted problems, which the field is focused on; think developing intuition rather than learning specifics alone.

- AI is wide-ranging, and so is the class. 

- Assignments: for the most part, well-thought-out. Even the more difficult assignments build your understanding brick-by-brick, helping you to build your understanding using incremental challenges

- Some TAs are exceptional, and go above and beyond.

- Thad's lectures are very helpful.

The bad (I’m not even doing bullets here; it’s just a description of the exam, so strap in and get ready to wonder how a piece of assessment can manage to be this poorly executed):


-Exams: Godawful. Utterly unacceptable. Think, pond scum speech from My Best Friend's Wedding-type bad.

I genuinely can't fathom how this class, despite having been around for (give or take) 10 years, still manages to be so poorly organized that LITERALLY EVERY SINGLE EXAM, EVERY SINGLE SEMESTER (read the OMS Central reviews if you doubt this) students all consider it a fiasco.

The exam questions, which can be unclear (though you have a week to complete them), may get answered, but also, may not; it's all TA-dependent. I asked a couple, and got a single response. The TA that was in charge of the other question just decided to pull the ol' Homer Simpson-retreating-into-the-hedge move, so I had no idea whether I was understanding the requirements or not. 

To boot, there is always a lengthy, running thread of corrections because either the Prof, or the TAs, are incapable of putting together an assessment that doesn't require addendums or errata. If you work on a question and it gets updated during the exam period (and you can be guaranteed that it will get updated), maybe you'll be ok, or maybe you'll have to redo it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. That's just the random reinforcement schedule you're on when you take AI exams — think the sort of thrill you get when you're playing slots, except it's with your grades.

Immediately following the exam, when the forums are reopened (they only permit private posting during the exam), it explodes with a flurry of "+1" comments as students, shocked by the fact that their grades are drastically lower than what they expected. 

Take this class if you’re happy to deal with the nonsense above for the sake of genuinely interesting material mentioned earlier on in the review.

Before I dive into this diatribe, I would like to say the material explored in this course is very interesting and eye opening. It has seriously made me consider if I should do a PhD in Artificial Intelligence and it helped me better understand graph algorithms, machine learning, statistics, and linear algebra. Overall, the material is fascinating, and the projects are very cool and interesting even though the difficulty of it is sometimes asinine.

But, there's one major drawback to all of this and this might be semester specific.

The organization of this course is a disaster. From the word go, there was miscommunications about what was expected from students grade wise in the first 2 weeks of the course.
In the first week of the course, the professor decided to try to make omscs students attend zoom lectures at 8 pm (the link to these lectures were always broken and you couldn't get in unless someone from the in-person course had a link) which was odd because the way it normally works in omscs is that all lectures were available on day 1 for omscs students to watch the lectures at their own pace with respect to their work schedule. 
Then there was an Exercise requirement added to the gradebook. The only way you could get to know what the exercise was if you went to the live zoom lectures. At the live zoom lecture, you couldn't see what the Exercise problem was unless the professor zoomed in on the white board which he refused to do because it would "give away" the answer to the Exercise. Also, the exercises were not even available in the assignment modules despite being due by the weekend. All of this eventually got remedied when he announced that all exercises would have unlimited attempts and you could see your grade right away. This condition was not true for some exercises where students would take it and never receive the grade until after it was due. When students on Ed would ask where the grade was, the TAs would respond by saying they’re looking into it and then never fix the problem. Also, during the last two weeks of the course the TAs decided to announce that all exercise would be reopened and that you can all retake it if you want which flew in the face of what the entire staff said back in January which was to complete the exercises on time.

To add to all of this, going to office hours was the worst. Many office hours links led to empty rooms where the TA didn't show up for 50 min. When going to Ed to ask what happened to the office hours, not a single staff member would respond (this happened throughout the semester). Sometimes, if you were lucky, you would get a response from staff but not in the way you'd hope. The response would be an update to the office hours calendar: deleting the office hour slot you're currently in waiting for the TA to arrive. Essentially someone on staff will see the Ed post and update the calendar to reflect that the TA wasn't available but not make that announcement to anyone else. 

This isn't to mention some of the weird things that happened when you did get a TA. The staff would 50% of the time not know the answer at all (which in retrospect, the questions ended up having a basic yes or no answer that could've been easily answered by someone who actually completed the project) or you would post a code review for the TA to go over in a private post on Ed, the TA would never get to it, and then some random staff member will see your code review 2 days after the project due date and ask if you ever got your code review done. Needless to say, the TA staff seem like they're stretched thin because they're having to work with roughly 700+ students (including the undergraduates that signed up to take this extremely difficult course and get 0 graduate level credits out of it). This doesn't even get into how the midterm exams were handled.

During the midterm. Many questions were changed or updated but these changes were never made as an announcement via email or Ed. In total, about half of the questions had to he changed during the exam. And when the grades were released it never told you what questions you got right or wrong. 
When the answer keys were published outside of Canvas and on separate Ed boards for each question, no one was happy with what happened next. If you felt you got an incorrect grade, you had to request a regrade for a question you want partial credit on for example and find out the TAs who created those types of questions didn't want to give partial credit at all even though the question had multiple parts and comprised of 4 points for example. 
The questions themselves seem like they were written a bit unfairly. When you're focused on getting a massive project turned in every 2 weeks combined with reading from a difficult to read textbook, I don't know how the TAs that wrote the questions could conclude that the students were ready to answer these types of questions that were never explained thoroughly in the textbook nor explained at all in the lecture. Luckily, there were only a couple of questions that fell under that umbrella but still.... annoying. notice how I've said the TAs designed the exam? When the professor went over the exam he himself didn't know the correct answer for the questions 4 questions in and asked his TAs to go over the rest for him during class.
The final exam, luckily, was more fair but there were still a plethora of revisions during the final and then you had to go through a regarding process that was first said to happen only in private mode and then all of the sudden it's allowed to be held publicly. Also, the answer key which was supposed to be released 1 minute after the final closed got delayed by 12 hours and 40 minutes and then was released in a random order. For example, the answers for Constraint Satisfaction were released first then other answer keys were released several hours apart from each other: Disorganized. This doesn't even mention the fact that a week before the final exam, a TA made an announcement saying that the final was going to be worth 20% instead of the 15% they had in the syllabus. This caused a panic and the TA's response was always snarky until the professor came in and corrected the TA’s statement hours later.

Even though earlier I said the projects were interesting, I didn't mean that they were particularly fair. The problem with the projects is that each one expects you to be an expert in whatever the project is focusing on (navigation, Bayesian networks, machine learning, etc), but none of the lectures help with the projects because the lectures gloss over so much nuance it's not even worth it. The textbook is the place to go but that has a drawback of its own. If you're familiar with how math textbooks are written then you're OK. If not, then you're gonna spend a lot of time trying to understand the math lingo that comes from some of the chapters. 
Sometimes, the projects will want you to implement a function that was never explained in the textbook nor lecture so you must do additional reading outside of the course material. This is OK but it feels weird since the writing style in those readings are also dry and unhelpful and the project is due in 2 weeks along with readings from 2 or more chapters from the book. This doesn't include times where implementing pseudocode from the textbook ends up breaking your project or equations from the textbook that you have to implement are unfinished (this was especially true for the unsupervised learning project where the equations provided were missing a lot of information). 
There's also submission limits on gradescope for each project. 1 project only had 5 submissions allowed, others had 3 submissions every hour limit. Either way, the deployment of the projects were hackneyed. The course punished you for working ahead since some projects were overhauled sometimes the day of it being released publicly in the repos. Also, some students got a solution file for the whole project in their project folder for project 5. This resulted in the entire project folder getting deleted from everyone's repo and then it was reuploaded with no changes to the project so the solution key was still valid if you ended up downloading it early enough. On that note, project 6 had an update by the staff halfway through that increased the difficulty of the project overall.
I almost forgot to mention the plagiarism mechanism in the projects that literally don’t work. Here’s what I mean. The reason why the projects are in private repos for each student is because each project has a unique combination of hidden characters in the comments (in latin) that pertain to each student. This way, if one student copied from another and that student’s code had hidden latin characters that don’t match the unique combination then the student can be caught for cheating. However, some students noticed that their IDE’s couldn’t run their project due to the hidden latin characters so those lines of characters that to be deleted so the IDE’s can actually run the project. Then said student would turn in the project, get a 100%, and receive no penalty for deleting the plagiarism mechanism. This effectively means that the anti-cheat system only works if you let it.

In short, the course was ran by the TAs and not the professor. This class didn't feel like a Georgia Tech class, it felt like a graduate level class from an underfunded state university. It’s a shame that the professor of this course didn’t take more responsibility in running this course.

The course has challenging concepts with assignments and exam questions that test your understanding well. It was very satisfying to submit the assignment to Gradescope, pass all test cases, and get that green 100 text. The exam questions were like story-based puzzles which were also satisfying to solve. If you're a dedicated learner, I would highly recommend aspiring for full points on all assignments and exams even if you have to sacrifice multiple weekends and some days off work during the takehome exams. Why? Because you won't grow radically unless you challenge yourself radically.

You will learn some cool topics beyond just ML. In the real world, when you don't have a lot of data, you will know that clever algorithms can help you predict/solve a wide class of problems.

The hardest math parts are mostly based on probability. I found my strategy of taking Bayesian statistics first was actually very helpful in that regard. I ended the class with a very high A.

As I dive deeper into different ML/AI classes, the rigorous foundation set by this class will be helpful.

Background: Working in ML for 5 years and 10 years of overall experience. Prior course taken: AI4T, SAT, DL, CN. 

Lectures: These are great and interesting. They cover broader Ai topics. But Lectures alone will not be sufficient to solve the assignments and exams. The recommended book was helpful.

Exercises 5%: Before the start of the course, TA's posted that there will be a weekly quiz that can be attempted unlimited times before the deadline. It went well initially but after midterm, it didn't follow the schedule. We were not sure whether we have a quiz scheduled for the week or not. Anyways, one can easily get this 5%.

Assignments 60%: Best 5/6. Assignments are well organized except for the environment setup. I felt it would be better if they could provide a docker file for the assignments. I took some time to fix the env before starting each assignment. But it is not a major issue. I put in my best efforts to score well on the first 5 assignments including the extra credit. I did well (all >= 100)and skipped the last one HMM. I used the last few weeks for final prep.  Grading is Auto-graded and the feedback was helpful from Gradescope. I started the A1 and A2 well in advance and A1 took a lot of time. 

Plagiarism Quiz & Intro Assignment 5%: The easiest way to score 5%

Exam 30%: The questions were hard and really will test your understanding. It requires a lot of time. I took a few days off for doing both exams as it requires a lot of reading and sometimes coding. The topics are mostly covered in the lecture and book. It is an open book, open notes, and take-home exam. Grading and clarifications during the exam were messed up. We need to keep following many Ed threads for updates when you are already investing so much time in solving the problems. I feel TAs should have reviewed and finalized a robust rubric before releasing the exams. There were a lot of regarding discussions and arguments post the exam. I scored 95% in the midterm since I want to score as much as I can in the midterm since the final is cumulative and will be difficult. I knew I just need more than 50 to get an A and so I did well enough to score 80% in the final. I got an A 97.95%. If I didn't perform initially, I can imagine the amount of pressure during the final and its regrading. TAs did their best but could have prepared the exam material well in advance and done more reviews.

I didnt attend any of the OHs. The previous exam walkthrough videos by TAs were very helpful. TAs are very responsive in Ed. One should have decent Python, and Numpy skills as a req. Else, It will be more demanding. Start early and score as much as you can before the midterm. Focus on the assignments more. Overall, it is a good course who likes to code and solve problems. You will learn a lot of AI topics.

I'd give a 0 for rating and 6 for difficulty if it were possible.

This class is relentless. 6 difficult projects, 2 seemingly impossible exams. Each project is released as soon as the last one closes. There's no room to breath and digest the material. The entire course feels like a fight to keep your head above water on the assignments.

The teaching assistants were at times unprofessional on Ed with responses to student questions.

The only reason I passed this semester is that we had a great cohort on Discord that helped teach each-other.

The exams were incredibly unorganized. During the exams, course staff maintained these long clarification threads for each question that you were expected to check daily. After the exams, there were mile long "regrade request" threads for each question filled with students "+1"ing each-other, requesting credit because the question was incoherent to begin with.

OMS admin need to audit this course.

This was my second class in OMSCS, first being ML4T. This course covers a lot of topics of AI. The book is amazing and I would highly recommend buying it.
We were lucky this semester that some of the hardest parts of assigments  were converted to extra credits and final exam was 15 points instead of normal 20. 5 points for 10 exercises were freebies (unlimited attempts)!

A#1:Search: This was the hardest assignment. Tri-A* (or any other method for Tri search) with optimal node expansion. At least 30 hours!
A#2:Game(or Adversarial search), it was easy, I had spend around 10-15 hours!
A#3: Probability and Bayes Net: This assignment is little tricky but not difficult. I spend around 20 hours.
A#4: Decision Trees: This is not very difficult assignment, and particularly I had implemented similar (less difficult) Decision Tree in ML4T course. Around 15 hours.
A#5: K-means clustering and Expectation Maximization: This is assignment can become tricky as you have to vectorize your implementation otherwise it will not pass Gradescope time limit. I would say 15-20 hours.
A#6: HMM: I did not really spend much time on this one as I already had above 100% on first 5 assignments (you can discard one lowest grade assignment so best 5 out of 6 assignments)
Mid-term(15 points) and Finals(15 points) are take home exams (7 days to finish) but exams are not easy. You have spend a lot of time doing each problem (you are basically solving each problem). Finals is cumulative so it cover entire curriculum (around 40% from first half and 60% second half).
If you want to score an A (which is not difficult), you have to score very high (almost 100%) in assignments. I would highly recommend this course if you are willing to put in some long hours, but you will learn a lot of basic AI techniques!!

Just wrapped up the course. Overall I think I’m very lucky to register this term, when there are plenty of extra points here and there. The 5 exercise points are basically for free, and you get 3 extra points for simply creating a GitHub account.

- Search: the first assignment really knocked us over thoroughly. This is the hardest out of the whole course imho. Spent days on the tri-directional, thengiven up on the last section. Worked on it even on the plane (without much improvement). I ended up with 93.5 since the last section became a bonus. This would be the best assignment to drop, that’s why they put it as the 1st one.
- Game playing: I’m one of the lucky people that somehow the basic implementation without any adjustment just passed all immediately 105/100. Beside HMM, this assignment cost the least amount of efforts, 4 ~ 5 hours.
- Bayes: Not too hard but I couldn’t get the sampling part to work correctly so it took more time than expected. For some reasons I think this one is the most interesting. 100/100
- Decision tree: This took a reasonable amount of time, and it was satisfying when things work out. Great to code it step by step and see how the algorithm really work. The course also felt lighter by this point. 100/100
- Expectation Maximisation: People said it’s hard and requires lots of time so I dropped it and did not look back. Haven’t read the description. However, seems like almost everyone got 90+ according to the figure posted by TA, so consider it.
- HMM: quite easy and straight forward, also it takes like 1 minute of adjustment from 2a to finish 2b. If you don’t want to spent too much time passing Gradescope, this assignment is a gift. 100/100

The mid-term was difficult but also reasonable. The staffs were generous with the regrading as well: average grade jumped up bloody 10 points afterwards. I spent 2 solid days on it though, so I planned to get by the final with minimum efforts. Oh how silly I am.  

I only need 45 to pass with an A, so I decided to not watch the last 2 weeks of lecture (the lectures of this course isn’t half bad compared to others, but they are still, well .. lectures). They made up 40/100 points though. Okay, I’m confident I can get 45/60 out of the rest. But hell, this exam really seriously cost you your dear brain! There are no free points. You really have to think and implement and check and check again to get the correct answer. I still skipped the last 3 parts out of principle but doing the rest is no less effort than watching more lectures. I should have actually focused on those 40 points instead and scraped 5 points from the previous sections. 

Anyway, I ended up with 41 haha but after the corrections it will be at least 48, and unless there will be some crazy changes in the % I will barely have 90~91% final grade. The take away from this term is, it’s possible to plan and allocate your efforts to minimise the hours spent. Prepare to work seriously hard, there's no way around it, but do not lose hope after Search!

The exam organisation is a big mess, stressful for both sides. But the TA tried their best , they are super helpful and responsive. If Raymond Jia is still TA-ing when you take this course, you are lucky!

I just completed the final and the breadth of content you are expected to know at a deep level before going into the final is ridiculous. Thank god I only needed a few points to keep a B. This course is too big. Many topics could be removed and left for more specialized classes. Stuff like Deep Learning, Reinforcement Learning, etc. This course should really be basic AI up to some Machine Learning.

Projects
(lowest is dropped)
88.87   - Project 1 - Search                                  (Hard)
105.26 - Project 2 - Game Playing                      (Easy)
100      - Project 3 - Bayes Nets                           (Hard)
100      - Project 4 - Decision Trees                     (Easy)
100      - Project 5 - Gaussian Mixture Models   (Hard)
0          - Project 6 - Hidden Markov Models     (Skipped)

The projects are pretty decent. They just want you to understand material at a way deeper level than it is 'taught' in the lectures (if it's even in the lectures). Get ready to enroll in YouTube University. 

Some of the project topics are mentioned in passing in the lecture and are completely left for you to figure out. (Honestly, thinking about it now, most of the things you are assessed on are also just mentioned in passing in the lectures.) The majority of the material in the class is missing from the lectures. Having a study group is pretty much the only way you can get the grades I did on the projects (unless you are a super genius or aren't seeing the material for the first time). Many of the people in our group were on their second and third try with this class.

Exams
68.92 - Midterm 
40      - Final - cumulative exam :( 

Exams are loaded with ambiguity and simply unclear questions. The questions test your understanding of the questions, not the content. Tons of regrades were rightfully submitted. Class exam averages pre-regrades was around a 53 for both tests. Midterm average jumped about 10 points after regrades. 

I spent 30 hours on the midterm and refused to spend more than 15 hours on the final. I attempted about 60 points worth of questions on the final leaving many of the insane and lengthy sections blank. The exams are way harder than in the past (we got to see past exams; I wish I took those). We thought that since they made the midterm harder, they would make the final easier and reduce the difficulty gap between them. WRONG.

85.56% Overall

I have very mixed fillings about this class. The content and subject was great. I learned a lot of things that will be useful in years to come. That being said, the quality of the teacher and staff was very poor. As the class progressed the organization and lack of communication between staff was clear and cause lots of frustration for students. As an OMSCS student the professor made it clear to us that he cared more about catching plagiarism and cheating instead of growing an interest in the subject for the students. I felt ignored and left to fend for myself for a lot of the course while the professor merely said that the answers were "obvious". The professor sent the class a "how to succeed" message which mentioned that the difficulty was at the level it is because he wanted to prepare us for PHD level exams. As someone who is uninterested in pursuing a PHD, I found this incredibly strange. With the constant emphasis on plagiarism I felt there was a constant atmosphere of fear. I was afraid to collaborate with or ask fellow students for help. Further dividing us was the extra credit, which was design as a competition which only the top 5 people would get credit.

I believe the assignments were interested and were good at showing how to apply the theory to practical scenarios but the presentation, bad organization, and technical issues involved took a lot away from the experience.

The exams did not reflect what was given in the assignments. The lectures gave us a simple view of topics and when students took the exam we found that there were many "gotcha" questions and during the exam there were many corrections that cause confusion. Prior to the exam students spent a couple of days correcting the grading that the professor and staff did.

During the semester, the syllabus mentioned a portion of our grade was exercises distributed weekly. In the send half of the semester, distribution suddenly stopped as well as weekly announcements. 

Over all I wish that I could give this class a better rating but the negatives greatly out weighed the positives. The level of work, stress, frustration did not reflect the grades given to students. It felt as if we were taking a class that was worth twice the number of credits but only given half.

Perhaps this will be corrected in next iterations of this class but I am skeptical as there were students who have had to take this class more than twice. If you must take this class be emotionally prepared to have a large work load and to have inconsistent communication.

Assignment is ok and not so hard to pass.
Like other AI course, mid and final exam is like a different task not easy to get good marks (less than 70 % is normal)

the assignment task is 5/6 which means you only need to pass 5 assignments which will reduct your work load.

By the way, for me the most difficult assignment is assignment 1. do not know how to write tri-A* search.
 
if you mark 100% assignment, still get chance to win A.
Fun class, prepared to do lots of reading and learning!
I did not thoroughly track my hours per week. I think this is a great course. Not as difficult as people say if you put the hours into it.

AI is overall a great course. The TAs are very active, the lecture videos are great, and the homework are mostly fair and stimulating. It is a tough course, but if you're comfortable with Python and have ~20 hours /wk to dedicate to AI then you'll be OK. This semester I took AI along with Game AI and Cyber Physical Design/Analysis, and it was challenging at times but very doable (But I don't have many responsibilities outside of school ie. no job/kids). 
My one complaint would be the exams. The midterm and final exams are both take-home open-book exams and they are LONG, especially considering they have to be completed within a week. Especially the final. I spent ~20 hours on the midterm and ~30 hours on the final exam. For me, this is totally doable because of my flexible schedule but for other people it may be impossible to dedicate this much time to exams. The other weakness of the exams was the confusing questions. This was addressed by students on Ed during our class, but basically each exam question is written a bit like a story or prompt which helps keeps them interesting. However, this can sometimes cause the questions to be very convoluted and long, to the point where I don't understand what the question is asking. For reference, the final exam was a 60-page pdf. For the record, I scored above average on both exams and had a ~95 as my final grade. For people with jobs, I'd recommend taking a day or two off of work during the week of the midterm/final to give yourself extra time. Time is absolutely the biggest factor in being able to complete the exams on time. Also be sure to ask clarification questions as soon as you have them, and be aware that there are practice exams posted on under files in Canvas that can sometimes be helpful.

Overall, this is an outstanding course. I learned a great deal about many different AI topics and would highly recommend this course. My advice for succeeding in this course would be to not underestimate the workload and begin every assignment as early as possible.

### Overall
This course is a survey of AI topics including search, game playing, Bayesian networks, machine learning, planning and optimization, hidden markov models, and others. It is interesting and also pretty challenging. The organization of the course could use some improvement. Lecture quality is ok, the book is good but dense and difficult to understand all the math if you don't have a strong math background, and the projects are pretty good.

My background is I'm a recent career switcher to data engineering (1 year of experience) and come from an analytics background. I hadn't taken a math class for 15+ years prior to getting ready for OMSCS. Preparing for OMSCS, I took Discrete Math at community college, and self-studied calculus 1 and linear algebra. The more math background you have the better your learning will be.

### Projects
You can drop your lowest score out of 6 projects. There are times when you can pass all tests locally but will not pass all of Gradescope. This is not unique to AI, and other courses have this characteristic.

- Search (difficulty 9/10, my score 85): You use uniform cost search (Djikstra's) and A* to find the shortest path between points on a map. The difficulty increases with doing this in a bidirectional and then tridirectional way. This is the first project in OMSCS where despite putting in many additional hours, I could not push my score up.
- Game Playing (difficulty 8/10, my score 95): Use minimax and alphabeta pruning techniques on a game called isolation. I was not able to beat Peter's agent for the last 5 points.
- Bayes Nets (difficulty 5/10, my score 100): Create a Bayesian network using conditional probabilities provided in a table. Calculate conditional probabilities for various scenarios. Use Gibbs sampling and Metropolis Hastings sampling algorithms. You get a maximum of 5 submission attempts.
- Decision Trees (difficulty 6/10, my score 100): Use decision trees and random forests to find convergence on classification problem. This topic was interesting and fun to me. However, the Gradescope implementation is testing you on something hidden without telling you. I spent some hours on figuring out what this was, and in the end, it wasn't some major change to my code. If the instructions simply laid out certain kinds of cases to think about, it would have saved me several hours of tweaking where I learned nothing additional.
- Expectation Maximization (difficulty 8/10, my score 100): This project is heavy on linear algebra. You need to know dot products, inverses, determinants, and other matrix knowledge. You also need to use vectorized numpy functions. I found this project to be the most conceptually difficult.
- Hidden Markov Models (difficulty 5/10, my score 100): Create HMM's and use the Viterbi algorithm to determine the most likely outcome given some evidence. There is a limit of 10 submission attempts.

Each of my above scores was the median during my semester. One of the issues with the projects is on some of them I scored well, but I still didn't fully understand how or why it worked. You are provided some formulas or algorithms sometimes and you just need to implement them.

### Lectures
The production quality isn't at the top level of the best OMSCS courses. However, I like that Peter Norvig and Sebastian Thrun did a good portion of the lectures in addition to Thad Starner. The main gripe with the lectures is they oftentimes aren't enough to get you through a project or test. You need to supplement with outside resources.

### Tests
The midterm is worth 15% and the final is worth 20%. Each is a week-long take home test with open book, lectures, and other class materials. These tests are unique in that they force the student to review all the material which helps to reinforce the concepts. I liked that I did gain more knowledge from this, but I didn't like the process. The midterm was 45 pages and the final was 60 pages. It's just a long slog to get through them, and I took days off work to do them.

This was my first OMS course which I coupled with ML4T. So, my only points of comparison are previous undergrad in-person classes (CS) and ML4T.
Overall the course is strenuous and involves a lot of external reading for project completion. The lectures are superficial and I believe they should redo the whole series. The assignments vary in difficulty of implementation but they help you understand key concepts which I enjoyed. However, don't be fooled by most reviews which say that only the first 2 assignments are tough. The first assignment is definitely the toughest to implement and get the full points. The other assignments, although easier to implement, take up a lot of time because they are lengthy and need several iterations to optimize and debug code. In the end, 5/6 assignments are considered for grade and you should really be aiming for 495 or higher in order to have clear chances for an A. Most assignments have an extra credit section that can boost your overall score.
Coming to exams - midterm and final is a one-week open book exam. Beware that these exams really test your in-depth knowledge of the subject matter and you will need the full 7 days to read concepts from the book and recheck your calculations. Previous year's questions and challenge questions (posted by instructors at the end of every week for each module) really help here and the difficulty of the exams is at par with these challenge questions.
Overall, the class median reached around 90 and I managed to get an A. Unlike ML4T, lectures in this class are not in-depth for project implementation and heavy external reading is required. Exams are way tougher than the straightforward exams in ML4T (which tested direct lecture material).
